data.title: Everything Easy is Hard Again
data.quote: Let’s be more like that tortoise: diligent, direct, and purposeful.

data.title: What Does it Mean to Be "Full Stack"?
What Are You Working For?
data.author: Jack McDade
data.quote: Do the work to support your family. Do the work if you love it. Do the work to help others. Do enough, well enough, focused enough, so you don’t have to do more.

data.title: On Simplicity
data.author: Max Böck
data.quote: We assume that complex problems always require complex solutions. We try to solve complexity by inventing tools and technologies to address a problem; but in the process we create another layer of complexity that, in turn, causes its own set of issues.

data.title: Falling Into The Pit of Success
data.author: Jeff Atwood
data.quote: (…) a well-designed system makes it easy to do the right things and annoying (but not impossible) to do the wrong things.

data.title: Are You a Developer?
data.author: David Walsh
data.quote: Being a developer isn’t about summiting the top of the mountain of knowledge. It’s about climbing a hill and enjoying the view for a few moments—then spotting the next one and plodding on.

data.title: Finishing side projects
data.author: Tom MacWright
data.description: Don’t get lost in asking why, don’t plan too much, do balance between existing and new skills.

data.title: Why You Should Aim for 100 Rejections a Year
How to Make Good Code Reviews Better
Types of careers
data.description: On the three types of carrers and how to act accordingly.

data.title: Leadership Mode Activate
data.quote: As a leader, you’re in a position to solve bigger problems than you ever could by yourself, since you can deploy the full force of a team.

data.title: Complaint-Driven Development
data.quote: The only thing I've ever seen work is getting down deep and dirty in the trenches with your users, communicating with them and cultivating relationships.
data.author: Jeff Atwood

data.title: What’s Your $1 Billion Idea?
data.author: Doug Sundheim
data.quote: The questions that annoy, frustrate, or bother us are our greatest opportunities.  They poke us and get under our skin.  We’re naturally motivated to solve them.

data.title: I Have No Talent
data.author: John Nunemaker
data.quote: What I do have is a lot of practice. (…) The kind of practice where all of a sudden I realize that it is 2am and I’m exhausted physically so I should go to bed, but mentally I feel on fire so I let the code have me for another hour or two.

data.title: Nobody Hates Software More Than Software Developers
data.quote: I hate software – most of all and especially my own – because I know how hard it is to get it right.
data.author: Jeff Atwood

data.title: Sapiens: A Brief History of Humankind
data.author: Yuval Noah Harari
data.quote: Is there anything more dangerous than dissatisfied and irresponsible gods who don’t know what they want?

data.title: Why We Sleep
data.author: Matthew Walker
data.quote: Practice does not make perfect. It is practice, followed by a night of sleep, that leads to perfection.

data.title: Factfulness
data.author: Hans Rosling, Anna Rosling Rönnlund, Ola Rosling
data.quote: When we have a fact-based worldview, we can see that the world is not as bad as it seems—and we can see what we have to do to keep making it better.
